page.title: 06THE ROYAL GEORGE, KNUTSFORD
page.content: The Royal George boasts a history back to the 14th century although certainly from 1653 it was called the George and Dragon. It was a lively and important coaching inn. As well as accommodating country meetings, tooth pulling took place here! The Assembly Rooms, the setting for many scenes in Mrs. Gaskell's Cranford and other books, has also been witness to real life drama. Highwayman Higgins set off from here to rob Lady Warburton of the jewels he had seen her wearing here, and much later General Patton addressed his troops from the balcony. The George and Dragon became the Royal George in 1832 after the visit by Queen Victoria and her mother the Duchess of Kent. Other visitors of interest include Louis Napoleon 1847, the public executioner 1886 and Winston Churchill.
